titleproper.value:
Guide to the Gil Green Papers
                    <num>TAM.095</num>

author.value: Finding aid prepared by Peter Filardo

creation.value:
This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit
                <date>2012-03-29T17:32-0400</date>

abstract.label: Abstract
abstract.value:
Gil Green (1906-1997) was a Communist, a Smith Act defendant, and a prominent figure in the CPUSA through 1991. As a youth, he joined the Young Workers League (later the Young Communist League) eventually becoming its national secretary. From 1941-1945 and again from 1966-1968, Green was head of the Party in New York State and also briefly headed Illinois' Party organization. Convicted under the Smith Act in 1949, Green was impirsoned from 1956 until 1961. He left the Party in 1991 and founded the Committees of Correspondence. These papers include his correspondence, writings, documentation of his political activities, and FBI files regarding their investigation of him. 
                <emph render="bold">NOTE: this collection is stored offsite and advance notice is required for its use.</emph>

p.value:
Open for research without restrictions. 
                <emph render="bold">NOTE: this collection is stored offsite and advance notice is required for its use.</emph>

Published citations should take the following form: 
                <lb/>
                <lb/>Identification of item, date; Collection name; Collection number; box number; folder number; 
                <lb/>Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives 
                <lb/>Elmer Holmes Bobst Library 
                <lb/>70 Washington Square South 
                <lb/>New York, NY 10012, New York University Libraries.

<list>
                    <item>
                        <title render="italic">Marxism and the world today.</title>New York : New York State Committee, Communist Party, n.d. 23 p.</item>
                    <item>
                        <title render="italic">Youth confronts the Blue Eagle.</title>New York : Youth Publishers, November, 1933. 29 p.</item>
                    <item>
                        <title render="italic">United we stand : for peace and socialism.</title>New York : Workers Library Publishers, 1935. 63 p.</item>
                    <item>
                        <title render="italic">Young Communists and the unity of youth.</title>Speech delivered at the 7th World Congress of the Communist International. New York : Youth Publishers, October, 1935. 15 p.</item>
                    <item>
                        <title render="italic">Facing the 8th convention of the Young Communist League.</title>Report, delivered Jan. 1, 1937. New York : Young Communist League, n.d.</item>
                    <item>
                        <title render="italic">Make your dreams come true.</title>Report to the 8th national convention of the Young Communist League, New York City, May 2, 1937. New York : Workers Library Publishers, June, 1937. 47 p.</item>
                    <item>
                        <title render="italic">The truth about Soviet Russia.</title>New York : New Age Publishers, March, 1938. 48 p.</item>
                    <item>
                        <title render="italic">America must act now!</title>New York : Workers Library Publishers, November, 1941. 14 p.</item>
                    <item>
                        <title render="italic">New York State's wartime election.</title>New York : New York State Communist Party, September, 1942. 24 p.</item>
                    <item>
                        <title render="italic">Marxism and the world today.</title>New York : New York State Committee, Communist Party, [1944?]. 23 p.</item>
                    <item>
                        <title render="italic">The enemy forgotten.</title>New York, International Publishers [1956]. 318 p.</item>
                    <item>
                        <title render="italic">Revolution Cuban style; impressions of a recent visit.</title>New York, International Publishers [1970]. 125 p.</item>
                    <item>
                        <title render="italic">Terrorism - is it revolutionary?</title>New York : New Outlook Publishers, 1970. 40 p.</item>
                    <item>
                        <title render="italic">The new radicalism : anarchist or Marxist?</title>New York : International Publishers, 1971. 189 p.</item>
                    <item>
                        <title render="italic">What's happening to labor.</title>New York : International Publishers, 1976. 305 p.</item>
                    <item>
                        <title render="italic">Portugal's revolution.</title>New York : International Publishers, 1976. 99 p.</item>
                    <item>
                        <title render="italic">Cuba at 25 : the continuing revolution.</title>New York : International Publishers, 1983. 117 p.</item>
                    <item>
                        <title render="italic">Cold war fugitive : a personal story of the McCarthy years.</title>New York : International Publishers, 1984. 275 p.</item>
                </list>

The General Correspondence (most incoming, arranged alphabetically) is primarily with like-minded communists, ex-communists, other U.S. leftists, historians and other researchers, and is primarily concerned with communist history and with current events, radical thought and activity. There is also some family correspondence. Prominent and/or principal correspondents include: Harry Bridges, Lloyd Brown, David Engelstein, Sender Garlin, Dorothy Healey, Kate Hyndman, Lolita Lebron and other Puerto Rican radicals, Sidney Lens, Helen North (his second wife), Paul Robeson Jr., Bill Schneiderman, Pat Toohey, Saul Wellman and Leon Wofsy. The Addendum to this series consists of additional correspondence with David Englestein and Sender Garlin. The Prison Correspondence, arranged chronologically, consists of copies of (mostly outgoing) letters, most to his first wife (Lil Green, 1910-1964) and children, some to political associates and attorneys. The Political Activities, Associates and Writings series contains unpublished typescripts by Green and others, notably James Allen's memoir 
                <title render="italic">Marxist Publishing</title>(n.d., 44 pp.), 
                <title render="italic">A Labor Revolutionary in Detroit</title>(re Nat Ganley), and Green's 1968 notes on his remarks on Czechoslovakia at the CP's Central Committee meeting thereon; editorial files pertaining to the writing, publication and reception of several of Green's later books, notably his autobiographical 
                <title render="italic">Cold War Fugitive</title>(1984); third party correspondence of several of Green's political friends and associates, notably Lloyd Brown; and a file of Smith Act-related material obtained under the Freedom of Information Act. The last series, FBI Files, were also obtained by Green under the FOIA. 
                <emph render="bold">NOTE: this collection is stored offsite and advance notice is required for its use.</emph>
